comments.author: Lucius
comments.body: In my opinion, the biggest difference between Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies that were created after it is that Bitcoin has remained essentially unchanged from the Genesis block until today. Of course, throughout this time we had some upgrades that should have made Bitcoin more functional considering the fact that its user base has increased over the years from a few tens of people to several million.Everything else that appeared after tried to compete with Bitcoin in some way, whether it was about max coin supply, block size or forcing POS as some kind of "better" POW alternative. It's no secret that every altcoin that is based on POS, has x100 more max supply and it is premined can not be in the same category as Bitcoin.In other words, the only man who didn't ask for anything for himself and didn't get rich from his invention is Satoshi - everyone else did it for profit.

comments.author: Jon_Hodl
comments.body: Bitcoin is a decentralized electronic cash system that is truly outside the reach and control of any centralized entity. It relies on math and free-market incentives to reward miners for finding a number (nonce) that completes a math equation. When they complete this math equation, they win bitcoin. Bitcoin is a very pure and simple system that works like a machine. "Crypto" is a term that has been hijacked by a number of scammers who have pre-mined altcoins (shitcoins) to get unsuspecting noobs to purchase their coins in an attempt to make massive profits. When enough unsuspecting users buy their shitcoin, those who can print this coin out of nothing will sell all of theirs and drive the price down substantially.The bitcoin community is working to draw a clear difference between Bitcoin (an objective system that is based purely on math) vs altcoins/shitcoins/crypto (centralized scams that use cryptography to rob unsuspecting retail investors) which are attempting to ride the coat tails of Bitcoin and its honest incentives. Bitcoin is open, honest, and fair. Crypto is 99% scams. It might even be 100% scams.

comments.author: hatshepsut93
comments.body: This is a good and right question.When Bitcoin was created,  the word "cryptocurrency" didn't exist. In fact it wouldn't exist for quite some time until people started creating modified copies of Bitcoin. That's when the need for a more general term arouse.Originally "cryptocurrency" was defined as a currency that exists on a decentralized network of computers. But there are many cryptocurrencies that are not decentralized, and yet no one is bothered by this fact, despite their centralization defeating the whole purpose of cryptocurrency. This is because most people in crypto community only come here for high risk high reward trading and not actually to use cryptocurrency.Crypto ecosystem is so toxic and useless that we might as well abandon it and say that Bitcoin is what Satoshi described it - a peer to peer digital currency.

comments.author: Darker45
comments.body: Bitcoin is a cryptocurrency. It is a currency that uses cryptography in validating transactions and making sure the information are safe. So, Bitcoin is a cryptocurrency, but I'm afraid it isn't vice versa. Cryptocurrency is not Bitcoin. It now refers to thousands of other coins. Thus, when one speaks of cryptocurrencies, it is now referring to more than 20,000 of them. This has caused a little trouble with the term cryptocurrency. Many Bitcoin supporters don't want Bitcoin to be lumped together with the rest of what are called cryptocurrencies primarily because they aren't the kind of coins that Bitcoin is. The way they are designed, they somewhat betrayed the very reason why Bitcoin was created. And so, many would want Bitcoin to be separated from the rest of the cryptocurrencies resulting to slogans like Bitcoin, not crypto.

comments.author: pooya87
comments.body: Bitcoin is a cryptocurrency but not all cryptocurrencies are bitcoin! Like all thumbs are fingers but not all fingers are thumbs Usually when people say "crypto" or "cryptocurrency" they mean altcoins not bitcoin.Quote from: Edwardard on December 29, 2022, 01:16:11 PM(since it uses encryption to verify transactions)There is a difference between "cryptography" and "encryption". Encryption is a cryptography algorithm that encrypts a message into a ciphertext that can be decrypted using a key to get the message again.Bitcoin does NOT use encryption at all in its protocol (encryption is used for wallets but it is not part of the protocol). Bitcoin uses cryptography: hash algorithms for mining, computing block and tx hashes, etc. and asymmetric cryptography using an Elliptic Curve for its keys and signature generation in transactions.
